caption: Figure 1: Example of latent feature mining through chain of reasoning
description: This figure illustrates the process of latent feature mining using a chain of reasoning. It shows how latent features (program requirements) can be inferred from observed features (client's profile) through a series of logical steps.  The observed features are used to deduce intermediate predicates which are then used to infer the final latent features. This example uses a client's profile to determine the required programs (Education, Substance Abuse Treatment, Community Service) for their probation.

caption: Figure 2: Overview of latent feature inference framework.
description: This figure illustrates the four steps of the proposed latent feature inference framework. Step 1 involves formulating baseline rationales by humans, which guide LLMs to infer latent features. Step 2 focuses on augmenting the training data with synthetic rationales generated by LLMs in a self-instructed manner. Step 3 involves fine-tuning LLMs using the augmented data. Finally, step 4 uses fine-tuned LLMs to infer latent features from the observed features.

caption: Figure 3: Risk level prediction results: (a) Model accuracy; (b) F1 scores per-category. LR - logistic regression; MLP - Neural Networks; RF- random forest; GBT - Gradient Boosting Trees.
description: This figure presents the performance comparison of different models in predicting risk levels.  Model accuracy and F1 scores are shown for three risk categories (Moderate, High, Very High).  The figure highlights that the proposed method using GPT3.5 significantly outperforms traditional machine learning (ML) models, particularly in the 'Very High Risk' category, which often suffers from data imbalance issues.

caption: Figure 3: Risk level prediction results: (a) Model accuracy; (b) F1 scores per-category. LR - logistic regression; MLP - Neural Networks; RF- random forest; GBT - Gradient Boosting Trees.
description: This figure presents the performance comparison of different machine learning models in predicting risk levels.  Model accuracy and F1 scores (a measure of a model's precision and recall) are shown for three risk categories (Moderate, High, Very High).  The comparison includes traditional machine learning models (Logistic Regression, Multilayer Perceptron, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting Trees) and the proposed LLM-based approach. The results demonstrate that the LLM-based method achieves significantly higher accuracy and F1 score, particularly for the 'Very High Risk' category which is notoriously difficult for traditional models to predict accurately.

caption: Figure 4: Outcome prediction results: (a) Model performance with/without the inferred latent features (program requirements); (b) feature importance plot. LR - logistic regression; MLP - Neural Networks; GBT - Gradient Boosting Trees.
description: This figure presents the results of an outcome prediction task, comparing the performance of models with and without incorporating inferred latent features (program requirements).  Panel (a) shows the ROC AUC score and F1 score for logistic regression (LR), multi-layer perceptron (MLP), and gradient boosting trees (GBT) models, both with and without the additional latent features. Panel (b) displays a feature importance plot illustrating the relative importance of various features in predicting the outcome, highlighting the contribution of the inferred latent features.

caption: Figure 1: Example of latent feature mining through chain of reasoning
description: This figure illustrates the process of latent feature mining using a chain of reasoning.  It shows how observed features (X) of an individual (age, race, gender, etc.) are used to infer latent features (Z), which are not directly observed but influence outcomes. The process involves extracting predicates (P) from X and using these to deduce intermediate predicates (O) through logical reasoning.  Finally, the intermediate predicates lead to the inference of latent features (Z), in this case, the program requirements based on the profile.  The figure visually represents this multi-step reasoning process.

caption: Figure 2: Overview of latent feature inference framework.
description: This figure illustrates the four steps of the proposed latent feature inference framework.  Step 1 involves formulating baseline rationales that establish relationships between observed features (X) and latent features (Z). Step 2 augments the training data by generating synthetic rationales using LLMs. Step 3 fine-tunes LLMs using the augmented data to improve the accuracy and alignment of their reasoning. Finally, Step 4 utilizes the fine-tuned LLMs to infer latent features (Z) from observed features (X).

caption: Figure 3: Risk level prediction results: (a) Model accuracy; (b) F1 scores per-category. LR - logistic regression; MLP - Neural Networks; RF- random forest; GBT - Gradient Boosting Trees.
description: This figure presents the results of risk level prediction using different models.  Part (a) shows the model accuracy for each model, demonstrating the superiority of the proposed LLM approach. Part (b) breaks down the F1 score per risk level category (moderate, high, very high), highlighting the effectiveness of the LLM approach, particularly in the 'Very High Risk' category where other models struggle.

caption: Figure 3: Risk level prediction results: (a) Model accuracy; (b) F1 scores per-category. LR - logistic regression; MLP - Neural Networks; RF- random forest; GBT - Gradient Boosting Trees.
description: This figure presents the results of risk level prediction.  Two subfigures are shown, (a) shows overall model accuracy, and (b) presents F1 scores categorized by risk level (Moderate, High, Very High).  The results compare the performance of four different machine learning models (Logistic Regression, Multilayer Perceptron, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting Trees) with two methods utilizing LLMs, showing the improvement in accuracy and F1-score by incorporating latent features.
